section.title: Higher Order Derivatives
section.p: Seeing as the first derivative of f is a function in its own right, \fd{f} must have its own first derivative. The first derivative of \fd{f} is the second derivative of f and is symbolized as \sd{f} (f double-prime). Likewise, \td{f} (f triple-prime) is the first derivative of \sd{f}, the second derivative of \fd{f}, and the third derivative of f.

paragraphs.p: All of the graphical relationships you've established between f and \fd{f} work their way down the derivative chain; this is illustrated in .

statement.p: Extrapolating from , what must be true about f over intervals where \sd{f} is, respectively: positive, negative, or constantly zero?
A function, g, and its first three derivatives are shown in , although not in that order. Determine which curve is which function (g,\fd{g},\sd{g},\td{g}).

image.description: a function's curve that starts at the origin, initially moves almost flat to the right, but steadily increasing in steepness until about (0.5,1.5), where it begins losing steepness; it flattens out at about (1.1,1.3), reaching a peak; then it descends, crossing the x-axis at about 1.8, and moving down to about (2.7,-2), where it smoothly flattens out and turns around, moving upward, again crossing the x-axis at about 3.8, and then exiting the graph at about (4,0.3)

a function's curve that starts at -1 on the y-axis, initially moveing almost flat to the right, but eventually curving upward; it crosses the x-axis at about 1.75, and continues rising to a peak at about (2.8,1), where it smoothly bends back downward, exiting the graph at a little above (4,0)

a function's curve that starts at the origin with an upward slope, reach a peak at about (0.6,2) before smoothly bending downward; it crosses the x-axis at about 1.1, continuing downward to reach a low point of about (1.8,-3.5); the curve flattens out here and smoothly bends back upward, again crossing the x-axis at about 2.7, and continuing upward to a peak at about (3.4,2.3); the curve then smoothly bends back downward and exits the graph at about (4,1.5)

a function's curve that starts at the origin, initially moves almost flat to the right, but steadily increasing in steepness until about (1.2,0.8), where the curve begins to lose steepness; it reaches a peak at about (1.8,1.3), bending back down and corssing the x-axis at about 2.8; the curev continues downward and to the right, but flattening out as it exits the graph at about (4,-1)

introduction.p: Three containers are shown in . Each of the following questions are in reference to these containers.

image.description: a prism-like shape, with a top that is a large square and a bottom that is a small square
a prism-like shape, with a top that is a small square and a bottom that is a large square

statement.p: Suppose that water is being poured into each of the containers at a constant rate. Let h_a, h_b, and h_c be the heights (measured in ) of the liquid in containers respectively, t seconds after the water began to fill the containers. What would you expect the sign to be on the second derivative functions \sd{h_a}, \sd{h_b}, and \sd{h_c} while the containers are being filled? (Hint: Think about the shape of the curves y=\fe{h_a}{t}, y=\fe{h_b}{t}, and y=\fe{h_c}{t}.)

Suppose that water is being drained from each of the containers at a constant rate. Let h_a, h_b, and h_c be the heights (measured in ) of the liquid remaining in the containers t seconds after the water began to drain. What would you expect the sign to be on the second derivative functions \sd{h_a}, \sd{h_b}, and \sd{h_c} while the containers are being drained?

During the recession of 20082009, the total number of employed Americans decreased every month. One month a talking head on the television made the observation that at least the second derivative was positive this month. Why was it a good thing that the second derivative was positive?

During the early 1980s the problem was inflation. Every month the average price for a gallon of milk was higher than the month before. Was it a good thing when the second derivative of this function was positive? Explain.
